trial_identification.studytitle: Acute effects of dietary salt intake on blood vessel function
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Acute effects of dietary salt intake on endothelial function in healthy men and women with normal blood pressure

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal development and function of the cardiovascular system

interventions.interventions:
In a randomised cross-over design, participants will consume a test meal containing 65mmol of sodium or a low salt control meal containing 5mmol sodium on 2 separate study days with a 7 day washout period in between treatments.
The test meal will comprise of 100ml of Reduced Salt tomato soup made up with 150mL water with 3.8g of added salt (65mmol NaCl sodium chloride). Participants are asked to consume the test meal over a 5 minute period.
interventions.comparator: A control meal containing 5mmol sodium. This will comprise 100mL of Reduced Salt tomato soup made up with 150mL water with no added salt. Participants are asked to consume the test meal over a 5 minute period.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in endothelial function as measured by flow-mediated dilatation (%)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Flow-mediated dilatation is measured at each of the following time points: Baseline (15 minutes before test meal consumption); post meal consumption at 30minutes; 60minutes; 90minutes; 120minutes

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in endothelial function as measured by Reactive Hyperaemia-Peripheral Artery Tonometry (RH-PAT)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline (15 minutes before test meal consumption); post meal consumption at 30minutes; 60minutes; 90minutes; 120minutes

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in blood pressure (mmHg) as measured with sphygmomanometer
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline (15 minutes before test meal consumption); post meal consumption at 30minutes; 60minutes; 90minutes; 120minutes

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Body Mass Index (BMI) > 18.5 kg/m2 Systolic blood pressure <130mmHg Diastolic blood pressure <90mmHg Weight stable over the past 6 months
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Know metabolic disease such as liver or kidney disease Treated hypertension Previous clinical cardiovascular disease Use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, folate supplementation or systemic steroids Significant weight loss (>5% body weight) in preceding 6 months Unable to comprehend study protocol

trial_design.concealment: Central randomisation by computer was carried out by a person indpendent to the study
trial_design.sequence: Clinstat software is used to generate a randomised sequence
trial_design.designfeatures: All participants receive all the interventions in different sequences during the study. They act as their own control.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A high salt diet can damage the blood vessels so that they are less responsive and expand less to the need for greater blood flow. This may cause the accumulation of fat in the artery and lead to heart disease and strokes. There is research to suggest salt can decrease blood vessel function. We are testing whether a salty meal has any short-term effects on blood vessel function in healthy people. We are doing this because we previously showed a higher than recommended salt intake made blood vessel less responsive after 2 weeks.
